Other examples would be capital requirements for banks (relative to their risk weighed-assets) to act as a buffer zone to absorb losses and prevent them from being overleveraged (and avoid the great recession 2.0) and implementing liquidity requirements (this is often done via reserve ratio) to ensure banks can meet withdrawal demands (banks are a bit of a beast that is too prone to risk when it comes to making a profit. Another type of “regulation” I’m extremely in favor of is Stress Testing. It’s often hard to know whether a bank is going to make it through economic downturns and regulators need to find out via economic shocks to assess their situation and identify weak points in advance.

Comment: Pt.1   No, I am not saying that at all (not even close).  Rather, I am saying that "separation of church and state" is not quite what some people pretend it to be.   The term itself was penned as a result of a private, personal letter from President Jefferson to members of the Danbury Baptist association in 1802. That religious Baptist organization had heard rumors that the United States was going to adapt a national church (kind of like how the "Anglican Church" was the national religion of England). Jefferson's letter was a response to that concern.   In his letter, Jefferson wrote:  To messers. Nehemiah Dodge, Ephraim Robbins, & Stephen S. Nelson, a committee of the Danbury Baptist association in the state of Connecticut.  >Gentlemen  >The affectionate sentiments of esteem and approbation which you are so good as to express towards me, on behalf of the Danbury Baptist association, give me the highest satisfaction. my duties dictate a faithful and zealous pursuit of the interests of my constituents, & in proportion as they are persuaded of my fidelity to those duties, the discharge of them becomes more and more pleasing.  >Believing with you that religion is a matter which lies solely between Man & his God, that he owes account to none other for his faith or his worship, that the legitimate powers of government reach actions only, & not opinions, I contemplate with sovereign reverence that act of the whole American people which declared that their legislature should "*make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof*," thus **building a wall of separation between Church & State**. Adhering to this expression of the supreme will of the nation in behalf of the rights of conscience, I shall see with sincere satisfaction the progress of those sentiments which tend to restore to man all his natural rights, convinced he has no natural right in opposition to his social duties.  >I reciprocate your kind prayers for the protection & blessing of the common father and creator of man, and tender you for yourselves & your religious association, assurances of my high respect & esteem.  >Th Jefferson   Jan. 1. 1802.  [https://www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/9806/danpre.html](https://www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/9806/danpre.html)  Jefferson reassured these Danbury Baptists that the "wall of separation between Church and State" reinforces the "rights of conscience." That is, Jefferson quotes the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment and then argues that no one can be forced to violate such a conscience -- which is between man and his God -- when it comes to religious exercise.   Jefferson invokes this conscience as a Lockean "natural right" (which alludes to wording in both the Jefferson-penned Declaration as well as as his words in the Virginia Statute of Religious Liberty. Such language was often used as a definition definitional term for the Bill of Rights (i.e., being "natural" and why the state cannot impede them from "we the people of the United States").

Comment: Pt 2.  So, I do NOT believe that the Constitution allows for any establishment of a religion (whether denominational or even a wider, encompassing religion). As Jefferson noted, that *free exercise* of religion is a matter of conscience that can neither be *forced* (by the state) or *prohibited* (by the state).    Interestingly, while he penned the Declaration and the Virginia Statute for Religious Liberty (two of the three accomplishments listed on Jefferson's self-penned epitaph), Jefferson didn't pen the First Amendment. At the time of his letter to the Danbury Baptists, Jefferson was the third President of the United States. He was serving his first term of office (and the fourth presidential term for the nation).   So, to what extent did Jefferson practice "separation of church and state?" Essentially, nearly all schools were "parochial" at the time. Even the most secular of schools required Bible teachings and times for prayer in 1800. Both houses of Congress and the Supreme Court opened with prayer by different Christian ministers. Many parts of the federal government and most state governments employed chaplains (which most still do).   Jefferson's silence on such matters could be taken as accepting such practices as not violating his view of that wall between church and state. No one would be forced to participate. No one could be prohibited from participating either.   So, my idea of religious liberty is similar. You cannot force participation. However, there is nothing in the Constitution that prohibits acknowledgment or acceptance of or cooperation and association with religious groups either. As long as the conscience of the individual is not violated, then no one is having their rights infringed.

Comment: Thanks. I'm definitely NOT using AI either. 😎  As for a measurement determining the violation of an individual's conscience: I don't think that there is a way to measure. In fact, there might not be a *need* anyway. Simply put: A person should not be forced to violate their religious conscience.  I suppose that this difference is that it is clear that the state is not married to any religion/religious faith. The United States has no state religion. However, just because we don't have a national language (until the last three months), it didn't mean that state functions couldn't be in multiple languages either.  My point is that the individual right to faith extends to their exercise as well as their choice not to exercise. However, this doesn't mean that expressions of religious faith must be banned from all state functions, documents or meetings either.  Thanksgiving (a day of thanksgiving to God) is rooted back before the foundation of the United States of America. On the other hand, Christmas (celebrating the birth of Christ) has only been an official federal holiday for 155 years (since 1870). However, it had been a state holiday prior to that. Moreover, it has long been celebrated in both private and public (including federal) ways. This has included official state functions.  Using the most stiflingly secular interpretation of Jefferson's "separation of church and state" terminology, it has never applied to Christmas as a viable and almost universally-practiced state acknowledgement.  Remember: While the federal government prevented the establishment of a religion (as well as the free exercise of it), the individual states had established religions long after the Constitution was ratified. Most of the original colonies had close and official ties to the Church of England until the 19th Century. Massachusetts had a state religion of "Congregational Church" until 1833.  Oddly enough, it was because of Jefferson's Statute for Religious Liberty that Virginia first unattached itself to any "established" religion. Yet, even then, the state often had close ties to religious faith and practice. Given the prevailing existence of "established" state churches in the U.S. by the time Jefferson mentioned that "wall," it is likely (or, at least, my guess) that Jefferson meant that the 1st Amendment essentially prohibited the federal government from establishing a single, national religion OR prohibiting the individuals from exercising their faith (in private or public) as well as compelling individuals to violate their own religious consciences.
